bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 15, 1875

div1.p: Reed has not heard from Emilie Lawrence. He expresses affection for her relative Mrs. Vaughan.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 15, 1875
div1.p:
Day follows day,
and night to night succeeds, & yet
not one word from your sweet
self! What can be the matter? Have
you dropped me from the list of your
correspondents, my darling? Or is it
that some unlucky fate has o'er-
taken your letter? Oh! these misera-
ble Rail-roads & heartless post-mas-
ters! Perhaps, some careless one, of
the last-named tribe, has tossed
your darling letter on some lone-
ly, out-of-the-way shelf, little dream-
ing of my anxiety to receive it.
Can it be that you have not received
my letters? Two weeks ago, to-day (Tuesday)
I received a sweet message from you
& one that, at the same time, made me
anxious. I immediately replied to it
& carried my letter to Portsmouth on
Wednesday & saw it safely in the P.O.
In this one I told you that I should
expect a letter when I reached Ports-
mouth the following Tuesday. I also
wrote on Sunday & again on Friday,
after reaching home, enclosing Dr
Hoff's note. And yet, after waiting all
this long while, I have not heard so
much as one word from Murfreesboro!
I would not be so solicitous, did I not
think that your letter has been mis-
carried & that I will never get it- If
I only knew that you had not written,
I would be satisfied, since it is
one of my greatest pleasures to yield,
at all times, to your own good judge-
ment- I do not retreat from the posi-
tion I took, when in Murfreesboro,
to wit; write, my darling, whenever it is
suitable for you to do so; I shall,
at all times, be only too happy to hear
from you. Today, when no letter came,
Mrs Vaughan laughed heartily at my
discomforture & said, “I wouldn't have
a Sweet-heart, who neglected me
as yours does;” to which I quickly
replied, that I would have her as
my sweetheart, and love her too,
if she did not write but once a
year, provided I got the letter -- and
it is true! So that you perceive that
I am not complaining of any infre-
quency of writing on your part. I am
too well aware of the value of your
time & the many duteies, youthat are to be
performed; & am just as well as-
sured of your love as if you
wrote every day- Mrs V. does her best
at teasing me, but as I always ac-
knowledge the force of her arguments
she is, of course, unsuccessful. She
reminds me of you, more & more, every
day- Really, when she is talking in
another room, I can scarcely believe
that it is not you, so much is her voice
like yours- Her manner of expression &
her walk is an exact reproduction
of yours -- & for this, I love her- How
could I help loving her, when she re-
calls so vividly to my mind my own
precious Emilie! I trust that I stand
well in her estimation, but when I am
at home, I carry on so much fool-
ishly that I am afraid she will be
displeased. Certainly there is nothing
that I would not do to win her
love, & this same feeling I entertain
toward every member of your family.

I did not intend, however, in commen-
cing this letter, to write you a long one- This pleasure
I reserve till after the reception
of yours, which I trust will be to-
morrow- Excuse haste-
div1.closer:
Believe me, darling,
your affectionate & devoted, Walter.
